comment.author: 13877445@N06
comment._content:
Looks like they're marching down Strand Street (R559) opposite the harbor.  In my photo you can see the building on the right with the blue front and red side.  Looking at Google maps it may now be an Indian restaurant with a magenta paint job.
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/13877445@N06/3852754029/in/set-72157622007793485]

comment.author: 69047895@N00
comment._content: The shape of the hats reminds me of the ones used for the "carnaval" de Lantz in Euskadi (basque country). See that photo: flic.kr/p/9uhZM5

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/13877445@N06] It does indeed look as if that's the spot! Thank you.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/lecourtzabala] A little more colourful than plain straw. Guess all of these festivals have similar origins...

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: The wren the wren the king of all birds, St Stephens day was caught on the furze ...................... The wren was pronounced RAN of course.  When I was a nipper it was commonplace and people dressed up in all kinds of gear including what would now be termed drag.  This is a beauty!

comment.author: 90132726@N08
comment._content: photograph taken by michael diggin tralee not diggins as in the tags, yes it is dingle on the street beside the harbour

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/90132726@N08] I apologise, Michael. Complete human error, as I know your surname is Diggin! Now amended in tags.

P.S. You don't happen to know the year you took this, do you?
